it's a good video, and I agree with all his

but can you really own a timbre?

but, well, what is the sound of piano? is

now, first of all, I want to acknowledge that

they're both played on synthesizers, sure,

but what if there was?

I mean, legally, no, it wouldn't, but should

well, that depends on where we believe a musician's
tone comes from, and to understand that, we
have to start from the beginning.

back in the year 1830, British piano player
Richard Salaman heard a performance by Austrian

piano player Johann Hummel, who Salaman described
as playing, quote, "with ease and tranquil,

concentrated power; undeviating accuracy,
richness of tone and delicacy of touch."

notice how, in the same breath, Salaman praises
not just Hummel's tone, but also his touch,
power, and accuracy.

now this is definitely not the earliest use
of the word "tone" in this context, it's just

the earliest I could find in a relatively
limited search of old newspaper articles,

but it gives us a pretty good idea of what
an instrumentalist's tone was: it was their

playing technique, their dynamics, their articulation,
maybe even their rhythmic feel, and while

technique could certainly set a player's tone
apart, it's not something someone else could

easily steal, so there wasn't much of a need
for the concept of ownership.

it was just inherently, uniquely, yours, like
a singer's voice, but the actual timbre of

it could change drastically depending on which
piano you happened to be sitting at. of course,

much like today, players could be incredibly
picky about the hardware they were willing

to use, but the point is that a performer's
tone was effectively their ability to coax
pre-existing sounds out of their instrument.

as for who got credit for putting those sounds
there in the first place? that would largely
have been the instrument makers.

probably the most famous example of this was
Antonio Stradivari, better known by his latin
name, Stradivarius.

born in 1644, Stradivari was a violin-maker
who lived and worked in Cremona, Italy, and

the tone of his instruments remains legendary
to this day: they're often described as sounding

richer, stronger, and brighter than other
violins of the time, or even modern instruments.

now, how much of that is true and how much
is just confirmation bias is up for debate,

but the point is that, if you were playing
a Stradivarius, even if you were a virtuoso

in your own right, a lot of the credit for
your timbre belonged not to you, but to Stradivari.

now, I should note here that I'm talking about
the individual timbre of a specific instrumentalist:

composers could, of course, experiment with
timbre just by switching which instrument
played a part.

giving a melodic line to the violin, for instance,
would create a very different timbre from

giving it to the oboe, or harpsichord, or
trumpet, and you could further control that

timbre by instructing your performers to use
a specific playing technique like, say, sul

ponticello, where the violinist plays with
the bow really close to the bridge, creating
a high-end, nasal sound.

this still isn't entirely precise, though:
you're defining the broad-strokes timbre you

want used, but every performance will wind
up sounding slightly different based on factors

outside your control like, for instance, whether
the performer was lucky enough to own a Stradivarius.

besides, we're talking about ownership, and
it wouldn't be fair to say that any given
composer invented the idea of using violins.

that said, there were certainly some ways
that individual musicians could alter the
sound of their instrument.

setting aside playing technique, the best
example is probably the trumpet mute, which

is a device that you insert into the bell
of a trumpet in order to lower the volume

and change the timbre to something a little
less aggressively trumpety.

mutes could even be added or removed in the
middle of a performance as long as you had

a couple bars of rest, allowing a single trumpet
to play with two or more different tones as
the piece demanded.

however, these were still a fairly blunt tool:
you just put them in and they did their thing.

you had very little fine-grade control over
the effect of the mute, so really, it wasn't

all that much different from just switching
back and forth between two different instruments.
everything beyond that was, again, technique.

but that all changed around the middle of
the 20th century, most notably with the invention
of the Hammond organ.

originally marketed as a replacement for expensive
pipe organs in churches, it eventually found

its way into popular music after the introduction
of the Hammond B-3 in 1954.

but this wasn't just any instrument: it was
an electromechanical keyboard that used a

series of spinning tone wheels to produce
sound.

in order to control that sound, players had
a series of drawbars, each associated with

a different harmonic, which is basically just
a component frequency of a note.

performers could pull those drawbars to different
positions in order to change the relative

volumes of those harmonics, and as it turns
out, the relative volumes of a note's harmonics
is basically what timbre is.

or, I mean, it's actually a lot more complicated,
but for the sake of this video that's close
enough.

the point is, for the first time that I could
find, performers had direct, discrete control
over their own timbre.

sure, every sound they could make had been
intentionally built into the instrument, but

with hundreds of millions of possible settings,
it seems wrong to credit any individual sound

to Hammond, who had probably never heard it,
as opposed to the performer who actually found

the tone. and, importantly, this was no longer
about playing technique: the B-3 wasn't even
touch-sensitive.

it didn't matter how hard or soft you hit
the keys, the only thing that determined your
timbre was how you set the drawbars.

and it seems like this shift was felt by the
artists too.

when asked what his favorite drawbar settings
were, jazz organist Jimmy McGriff responded
"I don't tell nobody that.

that's my secret," and other organists were
similarly reticent to share exactly how they
achieved their signature tones.

I remember back in college one of my teachers
told me how, back in the day, it wasn't uncommon

for a gig to end with a loud thunk sound at
the end of the last song, as the organist

quickly shoved all their drawbars back in
so no one could look at their settings. and

it makes sense that they'd be defensive: if
you wanted to reproduce Hummel's tone, you'd

have to spend years learning to mimic his
specific playing style, but if you wanted

to copy McGriff's, you just had to look at
his instrument.

but when you think of an individual instrumentalist's
tone, I doubt many of you think of the B-3.

if you're like me, the first place your mind
goes is to the electric guitar, with timbre

pioneers like Jimi Hendrix, Roger Waters,
Brian May, and Eddie Van Halen.

the electric guitar has, of course, had some
level of timbre control almost since its inception:

very early designs like the Rickenbacker Frying
Pan had only a volume knob, but it wasn't

long before guitars came out with multiple
pick-ups and tone controls that would allow

a guitarist to modify the timbre of their
instrument as they played.

I don't think it's a coincidence, though,
that most of the people we think of when we

think of distinctive guitar tones rose to
prominence during or after the late 60s, because

that time period marked a revolution in guitar
technology: the invention of effect pedals.

well, that's not quite true: there were a
couple pedals floating around before that,

most famously the DeArmond Tremolo Control,
which worked by passing the signal through

an electrolytic fluid, but for the most part,
prior to the 60s, guitar effects were either

achieved by studio tricks and expensive, bulky
processing units, which were impractical to

use live, or they were just built into the
guitar amps themselves, which meant you could
only use the settings your amp came with.

that all changed in the 60s, though, when
transistor technology finally got good enough

to allow for the invention of stompboxes,
small, individual effect processors that you

could put in between your guitar and your
amp to modify the signal.

the first of these was the Maestro Fuzz Tone,
introduced in 1962 and made famous by the

Rolling Stones hit Satisfaction, and over
the course of the decade we saw the introduction

of many now-classic effect pedals like the
Cry Baby, the Octavia, and the Fuzz Face.

suddenly, guitarists could chain together
all sorts of different effects, building their

own custom pedal rigs in order to create the
perfect timbre.

unlike the Hammond, where the limited set
of drawbars meant that the number of possible

tones was massive but ultimately finite, there
was basically no limit to how many tones a

guitarist could achieve with enough creativity
and enough pedals.

add to that the fact that, unlike the Hammond,
the guitar is touch-sensitive, so guitarists

could add their own unique playing style on
top of the timbre they'd crafted, and it becomes

pretty clear why so many of these artists
were renowned not just for the notes they

played, but for the unique tones they used
to play them.

around this time, a guitarist's timbre became
an extension of their musical voice, something

that, in a very real and meaningful sense,
was uniquely identifiable as theirs.

but at the same time, another even bigger
revolution was brewing in the world of timbre:
the synthesizer.

while it's hard to pinpoint the first synthesizer
because it depends on what exactly you're

willing to count, the first recognizably modern
synthesizer was probably the Moog 900 Series,
which came out in 1964.

it struggled to find an audience, though,
and there was a lot of pushback to the idea

of a purely electronic instrument building
sounds not from any physical process but directly
from their component frequencies.

the 1968 release of Wendy Carlos's Switched
On Bach showed just what the instrument was

capable of, though, and the public slowly
began to warm to the idea.

but Moog's synthesizers were analog, which
made them big, bulky, and expensive, so in

the 80s there was a push toward digital synthesizers,
which could be made and sold much more cheaply.

probably the most important synth from that
time was the Yamaha DX7, released in 1983,

whose relatively low price point led to huge
commercial success and a significant increase

in the number of synths in popular music,
which you probably already know if you've
heard literally any song recorded in the 80s.

the DX7 was notoriously hard to program, though,
so many artists just used its presets, but

later synthesizers came with much better interfaces,
allowing for previously unimaginable levels
of individualized timbre control.

it's like the Hammond organ on steroids: depending
on what synth you use, you might have dozens

of different settings, each with hundreds
of possible values.

designing a timbre that no one has ever used
before becomes basically trivial.

like, check this out: (bang) I'd be willing

I mean, you've probably heard something similar

extremely unlikely.
unless you follow me on twitter.

and modern synthesizers can produce all sorts
of timbres from all across the spectrum.

they're not just square waves and sawtooths
anymore: they can sound like strings, or horns,

or bells, or they can just sound like really
complicated synths. and, much like the Hammond

organ, those distinctions aren't driven by
playing technique: while some synths are touch-sensitive

these days, their timbre is still primarily
based on the settings used, which means that

unlike, say, Hummel's tone, or even Hendrix's,
a synth artist's tone is almost entirely reproducible
by anyone who knows what those settings are.

so what does that mean? should musicians be
able to copyright specific synthetic timbres?
no.
absolutely not.

musical copyright is messed up enough as is,
we don't need to be creating new avenues for
bad-faith actors to abuse.

but I also don't think it's fair to compare
the ownership of a specific synth sound to

the ownership of the sound of an acoustic
instrument like a piano, because the inceptions
of the two timbres are fundamentally different.

I mean, look: the legal definition of a song
hasn't really changed much since the Copyright

Act of 1909, but the music it's attempting
to regulate definitely has.

individual, customizable timbre has become
a fundamental part of modern popular music

across genres, and while you still shouldn't
be able to copyright them, I think it's fair

to say that artists who develop their own
personal tones deserve some sense of ownership,
at least in a philosophical sense.

just, please, for the love of humanity, nobody
